text: Peripheral T lymphocytes from women with breast cancer exhibit abnormal protein expression of several signaling molecules .
We examined signaling molecules of peripheral blood T lymphocytes obtained from women with breast cancer .

In 6 of 14 patients , T lymphocytes displayed an impaired ability to translocate NFeB <extra_id_0> p65 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> ( <extra_id_0> Rel-A <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> ) following activation by anti-CD3 and <extra_id_0> IL-2 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> .

text: This observation was made despite normal cytoplasmic levels of the <extra_id_0> Rel-A <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> protein .

We also detected abnormally low levels of the signaling molecules <extra_id_0> T-cell receptor (TCR)-zeta <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> , <extra_id_0> ZAP-70 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> and <extra_id_0> p56lck <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> in 4 of 14 breast cancer patients , i.e . , defects in T-cell signaling molecules .

text: Abnormalities of I or more signaling molecules were found in 9 of 14 patients ; however , only 3 patients had T cells that exhibited all 5 defects .
Our data have implications for the detection of potentially dysfunctional T cells in patients with cancer .
For example , the analysis of only 1 signaling molecule may allow patients with significant defects in T-cell signaling to go unnoticed .
Finally , despite impaired <extra_id_0> Rel-A <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> translocation , T cells were capable of transcribing <extra_id_0> IL-2 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> .
